content:
The Act titled "Stop the Sale of Murderabilia Act of 2013" restricts mailing and delivery privileges of state and federal prisoners for commercial purposes. The Act "Stop the Sale of Murderabilia Act of 2013" amends Chapter 87 of title 18, United States Code, by adding restrictions on the mailing and delivery privileges of State and Federal prisoners for commercial purposes. Inmates convicted of a crime of violence who knowingly send property for commercial purposes can face fines and imprisonment of 6 months to 10 years. An indictment for this offense has no time limitation. The Act "Stop the Sale of Murderabilia Act of 2013" imposes restrictions on the mailing and delivery privileges of State and Federal prisoners for commercial purposes. Inmates violating this section may face fines and imprisonment. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons and State correctional agencies can establish guidelines to restrict inmate privileges. Exceptions include mailing to satisfy debts imposed by law or court orders. The financial obligations that can be incurred by inmates include legal judgments, fines, restitution, incarceration costs, and other mandated obligations by law or court order. Additionally, financial obligations can also be incurred through contracts for legal services, mortgages on the inmate's family residence, education or medical care, and insurance for life, health, home, or car. Inmates may need consent to transfer ownership of property, vehicle, or security if not incarcerated. Definitions include types of facilities and the term 'security' refers to certain assets. The term 'security' includes various financial instruments such as stocks, bonds, certificates of deposit, and investment contracts. The term 'security' encompasses financial instruments like stocks, bonds, certificates of deposit, and investment contracts. Additionally, it includes certificates of interest, participation, receipt, warrants, options, or rights to subscribe or purchase items, as well as blank forms related to these items. SEC. 3. CRIMINAL FORFEITURE: The court must order a defendant convicted of an offense under section 1794 to forfeit any property used in the offense or obtained from it. 

SEC. 4. CIVIL FORFEITURE: Civil forfeiture provisions are also included in the amendment. SEC. 4. CIVIL FORFEITURE: Any property subject to forfeiture under section 982(a)(9) of title 18, United States Code, may be forfeited to the United States in a civil action in accordance with the procedures set forth in chapter 46 of title 18, United States Code. 

SEC. 5. CIVIL REMEDIES: Any person aggrieved by conduct prohibited under section 1794 of title 18, United States Code, may bring a civil action in a United States district court for relief, including injunctive relief, compensatory and punitive damages, and costs of the civil action and attorney fees.
